questions.question_text: Founded by Joseph Smith in New York State in 1830, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter -Day Saints is today better known by what name ? One of this movement's religious texts, written by Smith, is entitled Book of [BLANK] .

Bronze work in South Asia is generally considered to have reached its apex during which largely maritime Tamil dynasty  that ruled much of Sri Lanka and what is now Southern India from the 9th to 13th centuries CE?

The Christ the Redeemer of the Andes statue lies on the border between Chile and which Argentine province , famed for its winemaking? This province's namesake capital was almost entirely destroyed by an earthquake in 1861.

An author , Spinell , conducts an affair with Gabriele fuelled by the music of Wagner in the novella Tristan , by which writer ? This man  also wrote a musically themed novel – influenced by Schoenberg and Adorno – about the fictional composer Adrian Leverkühn.
Telling of the struggle between the Taira and Minamoto clans at the end of the Genpei War, Heike Monogatari (The Tale of Heike)  is considered the national folk epic of which country ?

Léon Bakst designed the set and costumes for which ballet  choreographed by Vasily Nijinsky which caused controversy in 1912 due to its sexually suggestive final scene? This ballet is set to a symphonic ‘prelude’ written by Claude Debussy.
questions.answer: L'Après -midi d'un faune  (or The Afternoon of the Faun ,

translations.dutch: Voorspel op de namiddag van een
translations.mandarin: mùshén w ǔhòu Norwegian: Faunens ettermiddag

questions.question_text: In computer programming, what name  is given to a program that translates code written in one (usually high -level) language into a lower -level  language in order to execute the source code instructions?
The arm of the Indian Ocean that separates Madagascar from mainland Africa is a channel named after which country  that lies on the opposite side of the channel from Madagascar?

In which chronic autoimmune condition  does the body attack its own melanocytes, causing unpigmented patches on the skin? This name is sometimes used interchangeably with 'leucaderma', although the latter term is more properly reserved for a loss of pigmentation following a physical trauma.
What is the national flower  of India? The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) uses this flower as its party symbol.
questions.answer: lotus  (or pink lotus , sacred lotus , Indian lotus , Nelumbo nucifera ; do not accept

questions.question_text: Which king  succeeded Conrad I as ruler of East Francia in 918, supposedly having been fixing bird traps when told of his election? Through his son , Otto the Great, he began the Ottonian dynasty.

translations.dutch: Hendrik I  or Hendrik de Vogelaar
translations.french: Henri I  or Henri Ier de Saxe  or
translations.mandarin: hēnglì yísh ì Norwegian:  Henrik I  or Henrik

questions.question_text: Which Tuscan artist  painted several outdoor versions of the Annunciation, including one commissioned by Cosimo de Medici for the San Marco convent  (pictured) ? Another version by him includes a reference to the Garden of Eden on its left side.
questions.answer: Fra Angelico  (accept Angelico  if offered; accept Gui do di  Pietro

questions.question_text: Which very soft mineral , composed of hydrated magnesium silicate, is the reference mineral for 1 on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness?
Which novel ’s first volume features the recurring theme of the fictional Vinteuil Sonata , where it represents the protagonist’s love for Odette?

translations.danish: På sporet af den tabte tid
translations.dutch: Op zoek naar de verloren tijd
translations.mandarin: Zhuīyì sì shu ǐ niánhu á
translations.norwegian: På sporet av den tapte tid  Polish:  W poszukiwaniu straconego czasu
translations.swedish: På spaning efter den tid som

questions.question_text: The northern Mozambique Channel is home to the island of Mayotte, an overseas territory of which European country ?

In the Brothers Grimm fairy tale Die Bremer Stadtmusikanten (Town Musicians of Bremen) , four domestic animals leave their homes with the dream of becoming musicians in the title German city. The first animal to set out is which domesticated equine  that appears in a philosophical paradox named after the French priest Jean Buridan, who used it to satirize moral determinism?
In 2009, the Mormon Church built a temple in Brigham City, a settlement named after which man , who succeeded Smith as Mormon leader and who led his people from Illinois to the Salt Lake Valley?

Otto the Great’s early rule was marked by repeated military failure and war with his brother, but he managed to earn legitimacy and the support of his nobles following which battle  of 955 when he decisively defeated the Magyars?
What unrecognised state , a successor to one of the many British colonial holdings in Africa, gained independence in 1980 as the nation of Zimbabwe?
questions.answer: Rhodesia  (accept Southern Rhodesia  if offered  but do not accept

questions.question_text: Which Hindu deity  is often depicted sitting on a lotus throne and holding a lotus flower? Radha and Rukmini are among the eight avatars of this deity.

The subject of repatriation requests since Nigerian independence in 1960, several thousand sculptures and plaques (collectively described as 'bronzes' despite mostly being made of brass) were taken from the Royal Palace of the Oba of which kingdom around the turn of the 20th century and distributed between Western museums?
In terms of both population and area, which is the smallest of the provinces of Argentina ? Its capital c ity is often claimed  to be the world's southernmost city.

The Mabinogion  was compiled in the 12th and 13th centuries CE from earlier oral traditions and is considered a folk -epic of which language ? Among the stories told is that of Pwyll [poo -ull] Prince of Dyfed.

translations.mandarin: wēiěrshì y ǔ Norwegian: walisisk  or kymrisk  or velsk

questions.question_text: Léon Bakst designed the set for which 1910 ballet  that starred Nijinsky as the Golden Slave and was set to a symphonic poem by Nikolai Rimsky -Korsakov? In this work, the title character is represented by a rhapsodic solo violin theme, whereas the Sultan is represented by a whole -tone theme played on bass  instruments, which softens as the piece progresses.

translations.mandarin: shě hèlā chá dá  Polish: Szeherezada

questions.question_text: As well as being the official national flower of India, the lotus is also the unofficial national flower of which other Asian nation , where it inspired the design of the Bitexco Financial Tower, once the country ’s tallest skyscraper? Tatjana Soli’s The Lotus Eaters  tells the story of a photojournalist who enters into a love triangle in this country.
The second animal to set out in the Brothers Grimm tale is which creature  whose tendency to salivate upon hearing a bell won a Russian physiologist a Nobel Prize?
What name  is given to a computer program that is able to directly execute script or code instructions without requiring them to be compiled?

Addison's disease is an autoimmune condition affecting the adrenal glands, leading to a lack of the production of aldosterone and which steroid hormone  that plays a crucial role in regulating stress, metabolism, and the body's "fight -or-flight" response?

The reference mineral for 2 on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness is which form of calcium sulfate dihydrate ? One fine -grained variety of this mineral is known as alabaster and is used in sculpture.

The grape is also the main crop in this Argentine province, named after a winemaking region of Spain. Sharing its northern border with Catamarca in the country's northwest, this is which province  whose largest cities are its namesake capital and Chilecito, separated by the Sierra de Velasco mountains?
Brigham City and the Salt Lake Valley are in which state  of the USA that is today closely associated with Mormonism?
The Mahābhārata  and the Rāmāyaṇa are epics from the Indian subcontinent originally written in which ancient language ?

As with Fra Angelico’s versions, which artist  included a partially outdoor setting of the Annunciation as part of the fresco sequence The Legend of the True Cross  in which the Virgin Mary appears taken aback at the arrival of Gabriel? Christ carries a white flag with a red cross in this man’s version of The Resurrection.

translations.mandarin: píyēluó  · délá · fúl ǎng qiē sīk ǎ

accept: Francesca  if offered; accept Piero  di Benedetto

questions.question_text: Mayotte is claimed by this country, consisting of three islands in the Mozambique Channel. Moroni is the capital of which nation , the only country in the Arab League to be situated entirely in the Southern Hemisphere?

Before Kenya gained independence in 1963, it was the site of a rebellion against British colonial rule known by what name ? The main belligerent was the Kenya Land and Freedom Army, who were known by this nickname.

translations.mandarin: Máo máo  qǐyì Mau Mau  is all that is needed, and that is

questions.question_text: Tajaderos  are bronze artefacts found in western Mesoamerica and the northern Andes, sometimes known as ‘axe -money’ or ‘hoe money’, that served as a standardized currency. According to the Smithsonian, by the time of the Spanish Conquest, one tajadero  had a fixed worth equal to 8,000 of which seeds ? These seeds, important in Mesoamerican cuisine, were also commonly used as currency throughout the region.

Otto’s conquests of Italy were prompted by the desire for a marriage alliance with Adelaide, who had been imprisoned by the second Italian king of what name , who he deposed and forced to swear fealty to him?

Léon Bakst designed the set and costumes for Daphnis et Chloé , a ballet and concert piece by which composer ? One of this man's most famous compositions was commissioned by the dancer Ida Rubinstein , and choreographed by Bronislava Nijinska , and is built around an ostinato rhythm played on the snare drum.

Although Ethiopia was never colonised, a British military administrative body occupied the nation after Italian forces were repelled in 1941. This agreement was signed by which man  on behalf of Ethiopia? He ruled as Emperor until he was ousted in a 1974 coup.

translations.mandarin: hǎiěr · sàilā xī  yíshì  Polish: Hajle Syllasje  I

questions.question_text: Bronzetti  are bronze sculptures created by the Nuragic civilization that inhabited which European island  from the 18th century BCE until Roman times? The civilization takes its name from stone towers called nuraghe , around 7,000 of which have been identified on the island.

A program with strictly numerical instructions that can directly control the central processing unit of a computer, at the lowest level of abstraction, is written in  a type of language given what name ? The specific format of the instructions will depend on the computer’s instruction set architecture.

The Annunciation is depicted in the central panel of  the Annunc iation Triptych attributed to Robert Campin , which contains many symbolic elements such as a towel hanging next to a washbasin and an extinguished candle . By what name , after the aristocratic family that once owned the work, is this triptych better known?

Which novel  features repeated references to Beethoven’s 16th string quartet through its protagonist’s quoting of the ‘weighty resolution’ ‘es muss sein’? This allusion serves to bring him back to his partner following affairs, including one with the artist Sabina.

The name of which Argentine province  on the Paraguayan border, and its eponymous capital, come from an archaic Spanish word for ‘beautiful ’? The same name was once also used by Europeans for an island in East Asia that is the  antipode of this province .
The reference mineral for 10, the highest value, on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness is an allotrope of which chemical element ?

Both Graves' disease and Hashimoto's disease are autoimmune conditions that affect what endocrine gland ? Graves' disease causes overproduction of hormones from this body part, while Hashimoto's disease leads to underproduction.

What object , a popular symbol in Mormonism, provides the nickname of the state of Utah, and appears at the centre of the state's flag? This structure is seen as a symbol of industry, diligence, and unity.
The third animal to set out in the Brothers Grimm tale is which creature  that was trapped inside a box in a famous thought experiment named after an Austrian physicist?

The folk epic of the Malinke people, the Epic of Sundiata  tells the story of Sundiata Keita, the founder of which African Empire  that shared its name with a modern African nation with its capital at Bamako?
Pernicious anaemia is an autoimmune disease that causes the production of insufficient red blood cells due to a deficiency of which vitamin , also known as cobalamin?

An unusual depiction of the Annunciation, choosing the moment at which Gabriel explains how the conception is possible, was the final work by an artist with the first name Ambrogio. What is the surname  of this artist and his brother, Pietro, who were important members of the 14th century Sienese School?

The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland  existed as a British protectorate between 1953 and 1963. Following its dissolution, Nyasaland become independent under the leadership of Hastings Banda and adopted what new name ?

The Mozambique Channel was created around 180 million years ago when Madagascar separated from mainland Africa during the fragmentation of which supercontinent ? Along with Laurasia, this had been one of the two primary supercontinents created from the breakup of Pangaea during the Triassic.

The lotus -eaters are a race of carefree people, whose apathy is induced by eating from the lotus tree, described in Homer's Odyssey . They inspired The Lotos -Eaters , an 1832 poem by which English poet  who composed the work following a trip to Spain with his friend, Arthur Henry Hallam, whose death inspired another of this man's noted works ?

In seeking better relations with the Byzantine Empire, Otto wanted to secure a marriage alliance for his son but was ignored by Nikephoros Phokas. However, after Nikephoros’s assassination, his successor, John Tzimiskes, arranged for which woman , his niece, to wed the future Otto II, after which she became an important influence in the German court, especially on her son, Otto III?

Scheherazade  and Daphnis et Chloé  were choreographed by which dancer and choreographer , perhaps best known for choreographing the original production of L'Oiseau de feu (The Firebird) , for which Léon Bakst designed the sets? This Russian is also known for choreographing Le cygne (The Dying Swan)  for Anna Pavlova, as well as Petrushka  and Le Spectre de la rose  for the Ballets Russes.

The fourth animal to set out in the Brothers Grimm tale is which male domesticated bird ? The behavioural endocrinologist Frank A. Beach introduced the term ‘Coolidge effect ’ – to describe increased sexual vigour seen when an animal mates with multiple partner s – in honour of a story linking this bird to a quip made by President Calvin Coolidge.
Rubies and sapphires are varieties of which mineral , a crystalline form of aluminium oxide, that serves as the reference mineral for 9 on the Mohs scale of mineral hardness?

What term  is used for a low -level programming language that has a close correspondence to machine code, but also uses mnemonic statements to represent machine instructions to improve human -readability?

Which author wrote about Eloise McCormick, who pretends to be a virtuoso to give lessons to Tibor in the short story Cellists ? A musically themed novel by this author centres on the pianist, Mr Ryder, who arrives in an unnamed European town to give a concert he does not remember agreeing to.
Which legendary sea monster  of gigantic size, said to live off the coast of Norway, was first described in 1752 by the Norwegian bishop Pontoppidan?

translations.mandarin: nuówēi h ǎiguài or kèlā kěn

questions.question_text: In November 1978, the American  Congressman Leo Ryan was shot and killed after leading a fact -finding mission to which settlement ?

A surprising discovery as it had been held that these states should have the same energy, what name is given to the phenomenon of quantum electrodynamics  in which the 2 P one-half electron has a slightly lower energy than the 2 S? The phenomenon is named after its co -discoverer who would win the Nobel Prize in Physics for this discovery.

translations.mandarin: lánmǔ wèiyí The word for ‘shift’ varies from language

questions.question_text: Which Spanish city  was the birthplace of the Islamic scholar Ibn Rush d (Averroes ), the Jewish philosopher Maimonides , and the Roman poet Lucan?
Awarded the Prix Goncourt in 1954, which roman -à-clef by Simone de Beauvoir follows the personal lives of a close -knit group of French intellectuals from the end of WWII to the mid -1950s?

During World War II, the Fat Man atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki because thick clouds prevented the bomb being dropped on the original target.  That original target had been which ancient castle town  on Kyushu?
